raw_text:
Labour chooses Manchester
 
 The Labour Party will hold its 2006 autumn conference in Manchester and not Blackpool, it has been confirmed.
 
 The much trailed decision was ratified by Labour's ruling National Executive Committee in a break with the traditional choice of a seaside venue. It will be the first time since 1917 that the party has chosen Manchester to host the annual event. Blackpool will get the much smaller February spring conference instead in what will be seen as a placatory move.
 
 For years the main political parties have rotated between Blackpool, Bournemouth and Brighton. And the news the much larger annual conference is not to gather in Blackpool will be seen as a blow in the coastal resort. In 1998 the party said it would not return to Blackpool but did so in 2002. The following year Bournemouth hosted the event before the party signed a two year deal for Brighton to host the autumn conference.
 
 Colin Asplin, Blackpool Hotel Association said: "We have tried very hard to make sure they come back to Blackpool. "Obviously we have failed in that. I just hope Manchester can handle the crowds. "It amazes me that the Labour Party, which is a working class party, doesn't want to come to the main working class resort in the country." The exact cost to Blackpool in terms of lost revenue for hotel accommodation is not yet known but it is thought that block bookings will be taken at the major Manchester hotels after the official announcement.
llama3.2:1b: Labour has chosen Manchester as its 2006 autumn conference venue, replacing Blackpool.
This marks the first time since 1917 that Labour hosts its annual event in Manchester instead of Blackpool, which was previously chosen by all main political parties for several years.
llama3.2:3b: Labour Party chooses Manchester over Blackpool for 2006 autumn conference, marking a break from traditional seaside venues and a blow to the coastal resort's economy, with exact cost not yet known.

Blackpool will host a smaller February conference instead.

This decision was made by the National Executive Committee rather than being a decision from the party's ruling members, likely indicating a desire for greater representation or change.
Colleague Colin Asplin expressed hope that Manchester could handle the large crowds and added that it is surprising that Labour does not want to host there since they are working-class parties.

This move marks the first time Manchester will host the annual event, with Blackpool receiving the smaller February spring conference instead as part of efforts to placate disappointed party members who had previously requested returning to their hometowns.

This marks the first time since 1917 that Labour has selected Manchester as the host venue.
The decision was taken despite previous commitments to return to Blackpool.
It is seen as a blow for Blackpool's tourism industry, which traditionally hosts both Labour's autumn and spring conferences.
Colin Asplin of the Blackpool Hotel Association expresses disappointment but acknowledges it might be better that the conference does not return to Blackpool.

Manchester's decision to host the annual event has been seen as a result of the Labour Party’s ruling National Executive Committee which is debatable with the traditional choice of a seaside venue.
It will be the first time since 1927 that the party has chosen Manchester to host the annual event.
The party has also chosen Manchester for its larger February spring conference compared to Blackpool, which gets much smaller in what will be seen as a placatory move.
The main political parties have rotated between Blackpool, Bournemouth and Brighton.
For years, it has been seen that the news about the annual conference is not to gather in Blackpool but does so in Brighton.
In 1998, the party signed a two year deal for Brighton to host the autumn conference.
Blackpool Hotel Association stated: "We have tried very hard to make sure they come back to Blackpool."
It is definitely that they have failed in the effort.
However, it is believed that they are hoping Manchester can handle the crowds as they want to maintain their reputation and gain competitive advantage in the country.
The cost of blackpool hotel accommodation is yet unknown but it seems to be taken at major Manchester hotels after official announcement.
smollm:1.7b: The Labour Party chooses Manchester as its 2006 autumn conference venue, and this decision is made without explanation or justification.
The party has chosen Manchester for several years, and it is not surprising that they have chosen this location.
However, the choice of Blackpool instead is a significant blow to the party's reputation in the coastal resort.
The Labour Party will hold its 2006 autumn conference in Manchester and not Blackpool, which means that the party has chosen to host the event in a different location than it did previously.
This decision was made without explanation or justification, and it is clear that the party does not want to come back to Blackpool for this event.
The Labour Party has tried very hard to make sure they come back to Blackpool, but it seems that they have failed in their attempt.
It is surprising that the party, which is a working class party, doesn't want to come to the main working class resort in the country and instead chooses to host the event at a different location.

The exact cost to Blackpool in terms of lost revenue for hotel accommodation is not yet known, but it is thought that block bookings will be taken at the major Manchester hotels after the official announcement.
This means that Blackpool will likely lose some revenue from tourism and hospitality businesses in the city.

tinyllama:1.1b: Labour Party will hold its annual conference in Manchester rather than Blackpool.

Despite a long history of alternating between the two coastal resorts, Labour chose Manchester as the venue for the 2006 autumn conference, which is the first time it has hosted since its last visit to Blackpool in 1917.
The party has been criticized for not choosing Blackpool but opting for the smaller and less popular February spring conference instead.
This is a blow to the coastal resort, and the news that Manchester will be the venue for the annual conference is seen as a placatory move by Labour.
However, it is also not yet known how much lost revenues from hotel bookings will be suffered in terms of block bookings at major Manchester hotels.
tinydolphin:1.1b: In the UK, the Labour Party has decided to hold its autumn conference in Manchester instead of the traditional Blackpool location.
This decision has been met with criticism by some local businesses and residents who feel that Manchester is a better choice for accommodation, conference space, and economic benefits.
The main parties have been rotating their conferences between Blackpool, Bournemouth, and Brighton since 1998, but the Labour Party has chosen to leave Blackpool behind in favor of Manchester.
This decision raises questions about how effectively the party has managed its resources in previous years and whether it will continue to prioritize securing its main base for future conferences.

The exact cost for Blackpool is unknown at this time.
